chapter.title: Purpose
chapter.para: The plugin provides different functions for DB developers. It can:

listitem.para: Send SQL code to the server. Process results of the publishing in any form: result set, number of rows updated, stored procedure published (with error processing).
Browse the DB using standard VFS browser.
Download the content of the stored procedures, packages etc.

sect1.title: SQL server types
sect1.para: The plugin can work with virtually any type of SQL server (assuming presence of appropriate JDBC driver in ~/.jedit/jars or $JEDIT_HOME/jars or set in CLASSPATH environment variable ).

Each type of the server is given in the XML configuration file. These files stored in ~/.jedit/sql/serverTypes or $JEDIT_HOME/sql/serverTypes (some configuration files - for Oracle, MySQL, PostgreSQL, DB2 are bundled with the plugin). Each file contains the following info:

itemizedlist.listitem: The name of the JDBC driver (optional - if driver is already registered by JVM itself, there is no need to register it in the plugin).
Configuration parameters. They are used to generate UI for managing servers and create connection strings.
Different service SQL statements.

sect1.para: For an example of SQL server type configuration type, see here .
All the server types are loaded during the plugin initialization
If the configuration file, JDBC driver, and (optionally) db-specific VFS are loaded without prolems, the server type is "registered"
The support of each particular SQL server type can be considered as a set of functions available for this server type:

itemizedlist.listitem: Standard queries - ability to perform queries from the buffer/selection
Stored procedures management - ability to distinguish usual DDL and DML queries from procedure-managing execution. Support for "Load Object" commands.
SqlVFS - basic support for SqlVFS. Ability to browse groups of tables and tables
Db-specific SqlVFS - existence of special db-specific class (subclass of sql.SqlSubVFS) providing special variant of VFS

sect1.title: SQL server records
sect1.para: Each concrete database instance, login, password, it is necessary to create and manage SQL server records. These records are set in Utilities>Global Options dialog, SQL tree item. The dialog shows the list of the existing server records, allows to create/edit/delete them.
Each server record "implements" one of existing and registered SQL server types.
For example, user can have 2 server types registered: Oracle and MySQL. With these types, he can create several server records for Oracle and some for MySQL

itemizedlist.listitem: Execute Buffer - Send current buffer entirely to the database. This buffer should contain a correct statement.
Execute Buffer On Server - Sends current buffer to the database of user choice (dialog is displayed before publishing). The selection should contain a correct statement.
Execute Selection - Sends current selection to the database. The selection should contain a correct statement.
Execute Selection On Server - Sends current selection to the database of user choice (dialog is displayed before publishing). The selection should contain a correct statement.
Load Object - Downloads the object sources from the database. Creates new buffer. In the drop-down list, red objects are invalid ones, black ones are valid.
Load Object From Server - Downloads the object sources from the database of user choice (dialog is displayed before publishing). Creates new buffer.

chapter.title: SQL Result Set dockable
chapter.para: During the execution of the SQL statements and after them, the dockable "SQL Result Set" displays the info about the execution process and its result (if the result is a set of records).
The result set is displayed as a table control with column names shown as headers.
The number of records displayed is restricted by the configuration parameter set in SQL plugin configuration panel.

The popup menu contains the commands manipulating with the data in the table control:
Copy all to CSV - copies all the data into the clipboard in textual "comma separated value" format. The data is taken from the table control, not from the actual result set, so it is has the same limit on the number of records.
Moving the mouse over the column headers (containing the names of the columns in the result set) user gets tooltips with metainformation about each particular column type.

chapter.title: SqlVFS
chapter.para: The plugin supports the browsing of SQL servers. To access the SqlVFS tree, use the More>Databases menu item in the File System Browser.
Basic SqlVFS provides 3-level tree (server records, group of tables, tables). In order to support it, it is sufficient to modify server type configuration file.

Db-specific SqlVFS can provide any vision of the database (browsing of stored procedures, views, synonyms etc) but it requires some special db-specific Java class. For example, see sql.serverTypes.OracleVFS.
